summary_reasoning: The report demonstrates strong analytical depth with clear causal linkages, explicit assumptions, quantified sensitivities, and decision-relevant implications. Causality is articulated between segment dynamics and outcomes (e.g., data-center mix and export curbs driving margins), and forecasts are anchored to drivers like AI demand, product mix, and supply constraints. Assumptions are explicit and partly benchmarked to history and peers: gross margin anchored near the 2024 level, terminal growth tied to macro, and valuation metrics compared to peer ranges. Quantification is pervasive, including WACC (~8.5%), tax rate (15%), margins and multi-year revenue/earnings forecasts. Importantly, the report offers quantified sensitivities and scenarios—EPS impact per $1B added sales, valuation sensitivity to WACC/terminal growth, and stress tests for China revenue and data-center stagnation—supporting decision-making alongside a fair-value target and upside. Weaknesses include limited mechanistic detail on how competition or TSMC capacity translate into pricing/margin trajectories and a relatively generic mid-teens CAGR assumption without segment granularity. Nonetheless, the breadth of quantified inputs and scenario work meets the highest bar for analytical depth. Verbatim excerpts: “driven by a 57% jump in data-center sales”; “will cut adjusted gross margins by ~11 percentage points”; “assume continued mid-teens topline CAGR thereafter”; “WACC (discount rate) ~8.5%”; “adds ~$10–15¢ EPS”; “could swing valuation by ±20%”.

missing_mechanisms: TSMC capacity constraints → impact on volumes/pricing not modeled
PC/gaming recovery → drivers for rebound not decomposed
unsupported_assumptions: mid-teens topline CAGR through 2026 without segment detail
EV/EBITDA near peers’ range without peer set disclosure
EPS doubling by FY2029 lacks cost/mix bridge
lack_of_sensitivity: No margin sensitivity to ASP/pricing changes
No segment-level scenario ranges for data center vs client
